questions.text: In District X with mid-year population of 1,20,000, during 2022, total of 2400 deaths were reported, among them 40 deaths out of 5000 cases were due to pneumonia. based on this information, calculate the case fatality rate of pneumonia in District X for 2022?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 0.8%

 

Option A:

 

Case Fatality Rate Calculation -

 

 

Number of deaths due to pneumonia are 40. Number of pneumonia cases are 5000.

 

So putting the values directly into the formula – we get (40/5000) x100 = 0.8%

 

Educational Objective:

 

Case Fatality Rate - 

 

  • CFR represents ‘killing power of a disease’
  • It is ‘closely related to virulence of organism
  • CFR = Total no. of deaths due to a disease/Total no. of cases due to a disease × 100
  • CFR is a Proportion: Always expressed in percentage
  • CFR is the ‘complement of Survival Rate’, thus CFR = 1 – Survival Rate

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 66.

questions.text: Analyze mortality data from a city with a total population of 1,44,000 during the year 2022. In that year, there were 3200 reported deaths, and out of those, 285 were due to road traffic accidents. Based on this information, calculate the proportionate mortality rate for road traffic accidents in this city for the year 2022.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 8.9%

 

Option B:

 

Proportional mortality rate means how many deaths of the total that are occurring at a geographic location in a given time, is due to a particular disease. It can be written as -

 

 

 No. of deaths from the RTA = 285

 

Total no. of deaths = 3200

 

Putting the values, we get (285/3200) x100 = 8.9%

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proportional mortality rate - PMR is number of deaths due to a particular cause (or in a specific age group) per 100 (or 1000) total deaths. PMR Is the ‘simplest measure of estimating the burden of a disease’. 

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 66.

questions.text: In 2018, an oncology outpatient department of a tertiary care hospital documented 180 breast cancer diagnoses. All diagnosed patients immediately commenced treatment. Upon reevaluation five years later, it was determined that 32 of the initially diagnosed patients had succumbed to the disease. Based on this information, calculate the 5-year survival rate for breast cancer patients treated at this hospital.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 82.2%

 

The question is asking about the survival rate of the patients with breast cancer.

 

 

No. of patients diagnosed with breast cancer are 180.

 

No. of patients died are 32, but to calculate the survival rate, we need to know how many survived. So, the number of patients who survived after treatment are 180-32 = 148.

 

Putting the values, we get (148/180) x100 = 82.2%

 

Educational Objective:

 

5-year survival rate –

 

  • Is used as ‘an index of success in cancer treatment’
  • Is not an appropriate measure to assess therapy that was introduced less than 5 years ago
  • WHENEVER screening is performed: Higher 5-year survival rate is observed; THIS IS A POTENTIAL BIAS DUE TO earlier diagnosis being made (and not because people live longer)

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 66.

questions.text: A researcher is analyzing different epidemiological measures to understand disease occurrence in a population. She needs to identify a measure where the numerator is not a part of the denominator. Which of the following measures fits this description?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ratio
 

Option B:

 

Ratio - expresses a relation in size between two random quantities. The numerator is not a component of the denominator. The numerator and denominator may involve an interval of time or may be instantaneous in time. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rate: A rate measures the occurrence of some particular event in a defined population during a given time-period. A rate comprises the following elements - numerator, denominator, time specification, and multiplier. 

 

Option C. Percentage: Numerator is a part of denominator in percentage

 

Option D. Proportion: A proportion is a ratio that indicates the relation in magnitude of a part of the whole. The numerator is always included in the denominator. A proportion is usually expressed as a percentage. Ex. Prevalence and Case fatality rate

 

Educational Objective:

 

Incidence is a rate; Prevalence is a proportion. 

 

Ratio is an epidemiological measure where the numerator is not part of the denominator. It compares two distinct entities.

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 63.

questions.text: A Public Health Consultant is evaluating the incidence of tuberculosis (TB) in a district with a population of 1,92,800. On January 1, 2021, there were 45 existing cases of TB. Throughout the year, an additional 32 new cases were reported. Calculate the incidence of TB in the district for the year 2021.
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 16.5 cases per lakh population

 

Option A.

 

 

No. of new cases of TB in 2021 was 32.

 

Population at risk is = 192800 - 45 = 1,92,755

 

Putting the values, we get – (32/1,92,755) x1000 = 16.6 cases per lac population.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Incidence: Is defined as the ‘no. of new cases’ occurring in a defined population during a specified period of time. Incidence is a RATE, expressed per 1000

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 68.

questions.text: In a longitudinal study, researchers are following a group of patients to understand the development of a certain disease. However, during the study period, some individuals were lost to follow-up due to death, migration, or other reasons, resulting in different follow-up times for different individuals. Which epidemiological measure is most appropriate for analyzing the development of the disease in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Incidence rate

 

Option C.

 

When different individuals are observed for different lengths of time, incidence rate (also called an incidence density) is calculated, in which the denominator consists of the sum of the units of time that each individual was at risk and was observed.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Incidence rate can be calculated from Cohort study
  • Cumulative incidence measures denominator only at the beginning of the study

 

Ref: Leon Gordis, 5th ed, pg 49.

questions.text: In a town having a population of 200,000 at midyear, 2,200 individuals were reported to have diabetes mellitus on January 1, 2022. Throughout that year, 450 new cases were diagnosed, and 75 individuals with diabetes mellitus passed away due to complications. Based on this information, calculate the point prevalence of diabetes mellitus in the town as of December 31, 2022.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 12.87 per 1000

 

Option B:

 

 Point prevalence of a disease is defined as the number of all current cases (old and new) of a disease at one point in time, in relation to a defined population.

 

Point prevalence (in percentage) is given by the formula:

 

                                ​​​​​​​    ​​​​​​​    ​​​

 

 

Point prevalence of diabetes mellitus on 31.12.2022

 

= {(2200-75) + 450} x 100 /(200000-75)

 

= 2575 x 100/ 199925

 

= 1.287 per 100

 

But, the options are in per 1000 population, so the answer is 12.87/1000 population

 

Educational Objective:

 

Point Prevalence is defined as Number of total cases at a given point of time


Period prevalence is defined by Number of total cases in a given year​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 45-year-old public health researcher is analyzing data from a small isolated island community where no migration has occurred for many years. The researcher is interested in understanding the prevalence of a chronic disease in this community. He recalls a formula that relates incidence and duration to prevalence, especially in stable populations where migration is not a concern. Under these conditions, how is prevalence best described?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Prevalence = Incidence x Duration

 

Option B:

 

  • Prevalence is a Proportion (Total=New + Old Cases): Numerator is a part of denominator, and is always expressed in percentage
    • Point Prevalence is defined as the number of total cases at a given point in time
    • Period prevalence is defined by the number of total cases in a given year
  • Prevalence describes the balance between incidence, mortality, and recovery
  • Prevalence can be determined from - Cross-Sectional Study

 

Educational Objective:

 

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence: Given the assumption that population is stable AND incidence & duration are unchanging,

 

Prevalence = Incidence × Mean duration of the disease

 

P = I × d

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 69

choices.text: Used when population is exposed to risk for a limited period of time
It is type of prevalence rate

questions.text: A local community has recently experienced an outbreak of a contagious disease. A team of epidemiologists has been dispatched to investigate the epidemic and to devise strategies to control the spread of the disease. During their discussions on various epidemiological measures, the topic of attack rate comes up. In the context of this epidemic investigation, which of the following statements regarding attack rate is NOT true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. It is type of prevalence rate

 

Option D.

 

Attack rate

 

  • It is an incidence rate (usually expressed as a percent).
  • Used only when the population is exposed to risk for a limited period of time such as during an epidemic.
  • It relates to the number of cases in the population at risk and reflects the extent of the epidemic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Attack rate is given by the formula:

 

 

Ref: Park 26th ed 69

choices.text: It includes both old and new cases

questions.text: In an ongoing discussion about epidemiological measures, a group of public health professionals are deliberating on the characteristics of prevalence. Which of the following statements about prevalence is not accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It is rate

 

Option B.

 

The term “disease prevalence” refers specifically to all current cases (old and new) existing at a given point in time, or over a period of time in a given population. Although referred to as a rate, prevalence rate is really a proportion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It reflects both new and existing cases: Correct. This is what distinguishes prevalence from incidence.

 

Option C. It is a type of proportion: Correct. Prevalence is mathematically a proportion, not a rate, as it lacks a time component in the denominator.

 

Option D. It is affected by the duration of disease: Correct. Chronic diseases with long duration (e.g., diabetes, asthma) tend to have high prevalence even with low incidence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Park 26th ed 69

questions.text: In a comparative epidemiological study, you are analyzing two diseases within the same population. Disease A has a prolonged duration of 10 years with a low incidence rate of 2 cases per 100,000 person-years. On the other hand, Disease B has a shorter duration of 4 years with an identical incidence rate of 2 cases per 100,000 person-years. When comparing the two diseases, which of the following statements is accurate regarding Disease A?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Higher prevalence

 

Option C.

 

Prevalence is influenced by both the incidence rate and the duration of the disease. Since Disease A has a longer duration than Disease B (10 years vs. 4 years), but they have the same incidence rate, Disease A will have a higher prevalence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Some Important Pointers -

 

If the prevalence is very low as compared to the incidence for a disease, it implies - Disease is very fatal and/or easily curable

 

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence: Given the assumption that population is stable AND incidence & duration are unchanging

 

  • Prevalence = Incidence × Mean duration of the disease P = I × d
  • Prevalence describes the balance between incidence, mortality and recovery
  • Incidence reflects causal factors
  • Duration reflects the prognostic factors

 

Ref: Leon gordis, 5th ed, pg 63

choices.text: The incidence of infection is 251,880 per year
The prevalence of infection is 251,880 per year
The mortality rate is 24.2 per 1,000 person
The 1-year cumulative incidence is 24.2 per 1,000 persons

questions.text: A novel virus has recently been identified in a country with a population of 10.4 million residents. In the year following its introduction, a total of 251,880 people were reported to have been infected by the virus. The infection is noted to have a low mortality rate. As a public health professional, you are required to determine the correct epidemiological measure to describe the extent of the disease spread in the first year. Which of the following is accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. The 1-year cumulative incidence is 24.2 per 1,000 persons

 

Option D.

 

1-year Cumulative incidence means total number of newly infected people in the population at risk in one year.

 

 

No. of infected people – 251880

 

Total population at risk – 10,400,000

 

Cumulative incidence = (251880/10400000) x 1000 = 24.2

 

Educational Objective:

 

Incidence: Is defined as the ‘no. of new cases’ occurring in a defined population during a specified period of time

 

Ref: Leon gordis, 5th ed, pg 64

choices.text: Determine the actual number of deaths that occurred in specific age groups in a population
Correct death rates for missing age information
Compare deaths in persons of the same age group
Eliminate the effects of differences in the age distributions of populations in comparing death rates

questions.text: In epidemiology, there are various methods used to compare mortality data between different populations or over different time periods. One of these methods includes age-adjusted death rates. What is the primary purpose of utilizing age-adjusted death rates?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Eliminate the effects of differences in the age distributions of populations in comparing death rates

 

Option D.

 

Standardized rates remove the confounding effect of different age structures and yield a single standardized or adjusted rate, by which the mortality experience can be compared directly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Standardization for the characteristic(s) responsible for the differences in comparison is necessary

 

Age and sex are two of the most common variables used for standardization and they are called Standardized rates

 

Ref: Leon gordis, 5th ed, pg 85

choices.text: The crude all-cause mortality rate is greater in men
The case-fatality from this disease is greater in women
The duration of this disease is shorter in men
Risk factors for the disease are more common in women

questions.text: A researcher is evaluating a dataset on a specific disease in a population and observes a perplexing trend. Although women in this population are being diagnosed with the disease at a rate five times higher than men, the prevalence of the disease appears to be the same for both genders. Given these circumstances, what is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. The case-fatality from this disease is greater in women

 

Option B:

 

Higher incidence of a disease in a specified population means number of new cases are higher in that population than the other. Prevalence means number of new cases plus old cases. So if in females, incidence is five times higher, it means number of new cases is higher. So, according to the question, in order to keep prevalence same in both male and female, if new cases are rising, it means old cases must decrease, which can also be said as – Case fatality from this disease is greater in women.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The crude all-cause mortality rate is greater in men: It’s a false statement. If mortality is higher in men, prevalence would be much lower in men. But the question mentions that the prevalence of the disease in both male and female is equal.

 

Option C. The duration of this disease is shorter in men: If the disease is of shorter duration, prevalence would decrease as compared to that in female.

 

Option D. Risk factors for the disease are more common in women: While more common risk factors in women could explain the higher diagnosis rate, it does not explain why the prevalence is the same in both genders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence: 


                Prevalence = Incidence × Mean duration of the disease


                P = I × d

 

  • Incidence reflects causal factors
  • Duration reflects the prognostic factors

 

Ref: Leon gordis, 5th ed, pg 86

questions.text: In the realm of public health and policy making, it is crucial to assess the impact of diseases not just in terms of mortality, but also in terms of the disability and reduced quality of life they cause. The policymakers in a certain region are focusing their efforts on interventions aimed at reducing premature disability caused by various health conditions. Which of the following indices would be the most appropriate and helpful for them to make informed decisions on where to allocate resources and which interventions to prioritize?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Disability-adjusted life-years

 

Option C.

 

The Disability-Adjusted Life Year (DALY) quantifies the burden of disease from mortality and morbidity. It's a measure that combines in one metric the time lived with disability and the time lost due to premature mortality. 

 

  • Years of Life Lost (YLL) = No of deaths × Expected remaining years of life (As per Global standard life expectancy – Japan)
  • Years Lost to Disability (YLD) = No of incident cases injury/illness × Average duration of disease × Weighting factor (0 Perfect health to 1 Death)
  • DALY = YLL + YLD

 

Educational Objective:

 

DALYs can measure ‘both mortality and disability together’

 

Case fatality rate measures ‘virulence of an organism’ or ‘killing power of a disease’

 

Dependency ratio measures the ‘need for society to provide for its’ younger and older groups’

 

Morbidity data measures ‘any departure from health’

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 26.

choices.text: United Nations

questions.text: During a seminar on global health initiatives, the presenter displayed a logo that caught everyone's attention. The emblem represents an organization with 6 regional offices worldwide, dedicated to ensuring the attainment of the highest possible level of health for all people. The logo features a staff entwined with a snake, a universally recognized symbol of medicine. Can you identify the logo of this organization?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. WHO

 

Option B:

 

The World Health Organization is a specialized, non-political, health agency of the United Nations, with headquarters at Geneva, Switzerland. In 1946, the Constitution was drafted by the “Technical Preparatory Committee’' under the chairmanship of Rene Sand and was approved in the same year by an International Health Conference of 51 nations in New York. The constitution came into force on 7th April 1948 which is celebrated every year as “World Health Day”.

 

Broad areas of work of WHO:

 

  • Prevention and control of specific diseases
  • Development of comprehensive health services
  • Family health
  • Environmental health
  • Health statistics
  • Bio-medical research
  • Health literature and information
  • Cooperation with other organisations

 

Explanation: 

 

 Option A. United Nations logo - 

 

 

Option C. UNICEF logo - 

 

 

Option D. UNDP logo 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Additional Information - 

 

  • WHO is unique among UN specialized agencies: It has its own constitution, own governing bodies, own membership and own budget
  • WHO 6 regional organizations & their HQ

 

 

Ref: Park 26th edition- page 1013

choices.text: i- d, ii- b, iii- a, iv- c
i- d, ii- c, iii- a, iv- b
i- b, ii- d, iii- a, iv- c
i- c, ii- d, iii- a, iv- b

questions.text: Match the following organization with its respective headquarters location.
questions.solution:
Ans. A. i- d, ii- b, iii- a, iv- c

 

Explanation:

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Agencies and HQ

 

 

Ref: - Park 23/e p921-923, 27/e p1026-1029

choices.text: It acts as the directing and coordinating authority on all international health work.
Concerned with the dissemination of statistics relating to health problems.
Acts as a clearing house for information on health problems.
Carries out research activities by itself.

questions.text: A 35-year-old researcher at the All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) in Delhi is preparing a presentation on global health institutions. She comes across a document that details the responsibilities and functions of the World Health Organization (WHO). She recalls her training where she learned about the varied roles that WHO plays in global health, from assisting countries in their health challenges to setting global health standards. However, she is unsure about one particular role of the WHO. Which of the following is NOT a responsibility of the World Health Organization (WHO)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Carries out research activities by itself.

 

 Option D:

 

The WHO does not itself do research but stimulates and coordinates research work. It has established a world-wide network of WHO collaborating centres, besides awarding grants to research workers and research institutions for promoting research.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. WHO’s first Constitutional function is to act as the directing and coordinating authority on all international health work.

 

Option B. From its earliest days in 1947, WHO has been concerned with the dissemination of a wide variety of morbidity and mortality statistics relating to health problems.

 

Option C. WHO acts as a clearing house for information on health problems, providing critical information and data to countries and health practitioners.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

WHO - Broad areas of work:

 

  1. Prevention and control of specific diseases
  2. Development of Comprehensive health services
  3. Family health
  4. Environmental health
  5. Health statistics
  6. Biomedical research
  7. Health literature and information
  8. Cooperation with other organization.

 

Ref:  Park 26th edition- page 1014-1015

questions.text: During a lecture on international health organizations, Assistant Professor Dr Raghav discussed the hierarchical structure and governance of the World Health Organization (WHO). He emphasized a specific body within WHO that holds paramount importance in decision-making. Which of the following is regarded as the "Health Parliament of Nations" and is the supreme governing body of WHO?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. The World Health Assembly.

 

Explanation:

 

World Health Assembly is the “Health Parliament of Nations and the supreme governing body of the organization. It meets annually, usually in May, and generally at the headquarters in Geneva, but from time to time in other countries.

 

The main functions of the Health Assembly are:

 

  • To determine international health policy and programmes
  • To review the work of the past year
  • To approve the budget needed for the following year.
  • To elect Member States to designate a person to serve for three years on the Executive Board, and to replace the retiring members.

 

The Secretariat is the Chief technical and administrative unit of WHO

 

Educational Objective:

 

World Health Assembly is the highest decision-making body of WHO, and is crucial for individuals involved in global health policy, as it highlights the democratic and collaborative nature of global health governance.

 

Ref:  Park 26th edition- page 1015

questions.text: During a workshop for community health workers in Mumbai, a representative from UNICEF discussed essential strategies for enhancing child health through the GOBI-FFF campaign. As a novice health worker, Rina attentively noted down the strategies mentioned in the talk. However, she later realizes that she might have included an item that is not part of the GOBI-FFF campaign. Based on your understanding, which of the following was NOT mentioned as a part of the GOBI-FFF campaign by UNICEF?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Food fortification

 

Option C:

 

UNICEF is promoting a campaign known as GOBI-FFF campaign to encourage strategies for a “child health revolution”. However, Food fortification, while an important public health measure, is not one of the components of the GOBI-FFF strategy as outlined by UNICEF.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Female education (F) is indeed a part of the GOBI-FFF campaign and focuses on the critical role of educating girls and women for overall health improvement.

 

Option B. Family spacing (F) is another element of the GOBI-FFF campaign, emphasizing the importance of planning and spacing births for the health of the mother and child.

 

Option D. Food supplementation (F) is a component of the GOBI-FFF strategy, aiming to provide additional nutrients to children's diets to combat malnutrition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GOBI-FFF campaign

 

G - growth charts to better monitor child development.

 

O - Oral rehydration to treat all mild and moderate dehydration.

 

B - Breast feeding.

 

I - Immunization.

 

F - Female education.

 

F - Family spacing.

 

F - Food supplementation

 

Ref:  Park 26th edition- pg 1016; 27/e p1029

choices.text: I- d, II- b, III- a, IV- c
I- d, II- c, III- a, IV- b
I- b, II- d, III- a, IV- c
I- c, II- d, III- a, IV- b

questions.text: Match the following organization and their activities.
questions.solution:
Ans. B.  I - d, II - c, III - a, IV - b

 

Explanation:

 

  • UNICEF has provided substantial aid to produce vaccines and sera in many countries. It has also assisted in the erection of a penicillin plant, near Pune; donated a DDT plant; two plants for the manufacture of triple vaccine and iodized salt.
  • The All-India Institute of Medical Sciences at New Delhi was established with financial assistance from New Zealand by Colombo plan (1950). This plan is drawn up for cooperative economic development of South and South East Asia (20 countries) with main aim to improve living standards of people, Industrial and agricultural development, support for Health Promotion (mostly via fellowships), Canada supplied Cobalt therapy units to medical institutions in India
  • Establishment of NIHAE: The Ford Foundation supported the establishment of the National Institute of Health Administration and Education at Delhi.
  • The establishment of the All-India Institute of Hygiene and Public Health at Kolkata was in a large measure due to the cooperation of the Rockefeller Foundation. The Rockefeller Foundation has been known to contribute to medical and scientific advancements, including support for pharmaceutical developments.

 

Ref:  Park 26th edition- page 1016, 1018

choices.text: Poliomyelitis due to wild virus

questions.text: In global health monitoring and disease reporting, international health authorities, as per the International Health Regulations (IHR), mandate the notification of certain diseases to the World Health Organization (WHO). This is required to help in rapid response and containment, especially for diseases that can pose serious global health threats. Which of the following diseases is NOT required by the IHR for mandatory notification to the WHO, even if a single case is identified?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Dengue

 

Option D:

 

The IHR requires countries to report certain diseases to WHO because of their potential to cause international spread and to require a coordinated international response. Smallpox, poliomyelitis due to wild-type virus, and Ebola are all diseases that require immediate notification to the WHO as they can have serious public health implications and may lead to international spread. Dengue fever, while it can cause significant outbreaks, is not part of the mandatory notification list unless it demonstrates unexpected or unusual public health events, as outlined by the IHR.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Smallpox requires immediate notification because it is already been eradicated; any new case would represent a significant event requiring rapid response.

 

Option B. Poliomyelitis due to wild virus also requires notification since the goal is global eradication, and any new case could signify a serious setback in this effort.

 

Option C. Ebola is highly contagious and often has a high mortality rate, making immediate notification essential to prevent an outbreak from becoming an epidemic with potential international spread.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Even one case of the following diseases needs to be notified to the WHO.

 

  • Smallpox
  • Poliomyelitis due to wild polio virus
  • Ebola
  • Human influenza caused by a new subtype, for example H5N1 in humans.
  • Severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS)

 

Ref:  Rajvir Bhalwar, Textbook of Community Medicine 4th edition- page 109

questions.text: Dr. Kumar, an infectious disease specialist in India, is discussing international collaborations in combating communicable diseases during a medical seminar in Delhi. He highlights the involvement of various international agencies in supporting public health initiatives. As part of his presentation, Dr. Kumar mentions the role of the Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency (SIDA) in providing financial support for healthcare initiatives in India. Which of the following communicable diseases has SIDA extended financial support for in India?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tuberculosis

 

Explanation:

 

SIDA (Swedish International Developmental Agency) is a government agency based in Sweden which promotes sustainable development and provides international aid around the world.

 

Its primary goal is to reduce poverty and global burden of the diseases. It works in collaboration with the governments, civil society organizations and other stakeholders to implement programs that are aimed to overcome the developmental challenges.

 

In India, SIDA has assisted in the NTEP program.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Organization funds for the National TB Program of India are - SIDA, WHO, World Bank

 

Ref:  Park 26th edition- page 1018

choices.text: 2 per 100 PY
20 per 100 PY
3 per 100 PY
30 per 100 PY

questions.text:
A study on ischemic heart disease (IHD) commenced in January 1991 and concluded in December 2000. Initially, 5 subjects were enrolled, with an additional 5 joining at different times during the study. By the end of 2000, 2 individuals had developed IHD. Given the follow-up details provided below, what is the incidence rate of IHD in this study?

 

 

Legend: > = Follow up starts; O = Follow up ends, subject remains without IHD; A = Subject died due to some other disease; ? = Subject was lost to follow up; X = Subject developed IHD
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3 per 100 PY

 

Option C.

 

Incidence rate is also known as ‘Incidence density'

 

Calculate the total person-years (PY) of follow-up for each subject:

 

  • Subject 1: 1991-2000 (10 years)
  • Subject 2: 1991-2000 (10 years)
  • Subject 3: 1991-1995 (5 years)
  • Subject 4: 1991-1998 (8 years)
  • Subject 5: 1991-1992 (1 year)
  • Subject 6: 1992-2000 (9 years)
  • Subject 7: 1993-1998 (6 years)
  • Subject 8: 1995-2000 (6 years)
  • Subject 9: 1995-1998 (4 years)
  • Subject 10: 1997-2000 (4 years)

 

Total duration of observation= 63 person years

 

Incidence density/rate = 2/63 = 0.03 PY = 3 per 100 person years

 

Educational Objective:

 

Incidence: Is defined as the ‘no. of new cases’ occurring in a defined population during a specified period of time. Incidence is a RATE, expressed per 1000

 

 

Incidence is the best measure of disease frequency in etiological studies

 

Incidence can be determined from: Cohort study

 

Ref: Park 27/e p69

choices.text: Mortality among coal workers is same as that of whole population
Coal workers has less mortality compared to whole population
Mortality is more in coal workers compared to whole population
Cannot be determined with above data

questions.text: A researcher conducted a study to analyze the mortality rates of coal workers. The standard mortality ratio (SMR) for the coal workers was found to be 112. Based on this information, how does the mortality rate of coal workers compare to the general population?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Mortality is more in coal workers compared to whole population

 

Option C:

 

 

 

 

 

If the ratio had value greater than 100, then the occupation would appear to carry a greater mortality risk than that of the whole population. If the ratio had value less than 100, then the occupation risks of mortality would seem to be proportionately less than that for the whole population.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Standard mortality ratio (SMR) is used to compare mortality rates between a study population and the general population. An SMR above 100 indicates higher mortality in the study population, an SMR below 100 indicates lower mortality, and an SMR of 100 indicates equal mortality rates.

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 68.

questions.text: During a global health conference in Mumbai, Dr. Patel emphasized the importance of international support for developing nations. He discussed the role of a specific international organization that has been instrumental in aiding poorer nations to harness their human and natural resources to their full potential. This organization not only provides financial support but also offers expertise in various developmental projects, from governance to environmental sustainability. Which organization is Dr. Patel most likely referring to?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. UNDP

 

Option B:

 

The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) was established in 1966. It is the main source of funds for technical assistance. The member countries of the United Nations meet annually and pledge contributions to the UNDP.

 

The basic objective of the UNDP is to help poorer nations develop their human and natural resources more fully. The UNDP projects cover virtually every economic and social sector - agriculture, industry, education and science, health, social welfare, etc.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. UNFPA, the United Nations Population Fund, focuses on reproductive health and population issues.

 

Option C. ILO, the International Labour Organization, specializes in labor issues, employment, and workplace rights.

 

Option D. FAO, the Food and Agriculture Organization, is focused on food security and agriculture.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

UNDP provides comprehensive development assistance that spans financial, technical, and policy support to help nations achieve sustainable development and effectively use their resources.

 

Ref:  Park 26th edition- page 1017

questions.text: In a lecture series on the evolution of health and welfare organizations in India, a professor emphasized the historical significance of certain organizations. The Indian Red Cross Society was highlighted for its monumental contributions to health, disaster management, and the welfare of vulnerable populations. The professor mentioned that this esteemed organization received formal recognition through a specific act of the Indian Legislature. In which year was the Indian Red Cross Society officially established by an act of the Indian Legislature?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1920

 

Explanation:

 

The Red Cross Society of India was established by an Act of the Indian Legislature in 1920.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

International Red Cross

 

  • Founded and Red Cross logo was designed by Henry Dunant
  • Head quarter in Geneva, Switzerland
  • The Red Cross logo was designed by Henri Dunant in 1863. The emblem of a red cross with arms of equal length on a white background is the visible sign of protection under the 1949 Geneva Conventions. As such, it is the emblem of the armed forces’ medical services.

 

Ref:  Park 26th edition- page 1019

questions.text: Dr. Priya, a public health officer in Mumbai, is organizing a community health awareness program. As part of her efforts to raise awareness about global health issues, she plans to highlight the themes of World Health Day over the past few years. Match the respective world health day theme with the year.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. i- c, ii- d, iii- b, iv- a

 

Explanation:

 

2020 - Support nurses and midwives
 

2021 - Building a fairer, healthier world for everyone
 

2022 - Our planet, our health
 

2023 - Health for All – 75 years of public Health

 

World Health Day is celebrated on 7th April

World Health Day themes –

choices.text: Events have a serious public health impact.
Event is usual and expected.
Risk of international spread
Risk of causing restrictions on international trade or travel

questions.text:
Dr. Raj, an infectious disease specialist in Chennai, is attending a seminar on global health emergencies. The seminar discusses the criteria used by international health organizations to identify diseases as Public Health Emergencies of International Concern (PHEIC). As part of the discussion, Dr. Raj raised a question about the criteria for declaring a PHEIC.

 

Which of the following is NOT one of the criteria for declaring a disease as PHEIC?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Event is usual and expected.

 

Option B:

 

The International Health Regulations (IHR) define certain criteria for declaring a PHEIC (Public Health Emergency of International Concern). These include a serious public health impact, the likelihood of international disease spread, and the potential for travel or trade restrictions. However, an event being "usual and expected" does not align with the criteria for a PHEIC.

 

In fact, a PHEIC is typically declared for events that are serious, sudden, unusual, or unexpected, which constitute a public health risk to other States through the international spread of disease and potentially require a coordinated international response.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Events that have a serious public health impact are considered for a PHEIC as they may necessitate immediate international attention and action.

 

Option C. The risk of international spread is a crucial factor since it implies that the event can cross borders and affect other countries, making it a concern for global health security.

 

Option D. The risk of restrictions on international trade or travel is also a factor as such restrictions can have significant repercussions on global movement and economy, warranting an international response to manage the event effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The main criteria for identifying any disease/event as a PHEIC are as follows:

 

  • Does the event have a serious public health impact?
  • Is the event unusual or unexpected?
  • Is there is a risk of the event spreading internationally?
  • Does the event carry a risk of causing restrictions on travel or trade?

 

The member states must assess public health events using the decision protocols and notify the WHO, within 24 hours, of all events that may constitute a PHEIC.

 

Ref:  Rajvir Bhalwar, Textbook of Community Medicine 4th edition- page 1096

questions.text: During a global health symposium, the moderator displayed a distinctive emblem representing an international organization. This organization, with its headquarters situated in New York, is primarily involved in promoting sexual and reproductive health rights worldwide. Which organization's logo was being shown?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. UNFPA

 

Option A:

 

The United Nations Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA) has been aiding India since 1974. 

 

UNFPA is the Highest funding agency for Population and Reproduction related programs; including the creation of national strategies and protocols, and the provision of supplies and services, worldwide. 

 

It has recently been known for its worldwide campaign against obstetric fistula and female genital mutilation.

 

Explanation: 

 

Option B. WHO logo - 

 

 

Option C. UNICEF logo -

 

 

Option D. UNDP logo - 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lead UN agency for delivering a world where every pregnancy is wanted, every childbirth is safe and every young person’s potential is fulfilled. Largest funding agency for the Population and Reproduction related programs. Organization has recently been known for its worldwide campaign against obstetric fistula and female genital mutilation.

 

Ref: Park 26th edition- page 1017

questions.text: At an international economics symposium at Shri Ram College of Commerce (SRCC) in Delhi, the faculty highlighted various global financial institutions. One emblem, in particular, was showcased, representing an organization dedicated to financial and technical assistance to developing countries. This organization's headquarters is located in the USA. Which organization's logo was being referred to?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. World Bank

 

Option C:

 

World Bank is a specialized agency of the United Nations. It was established with the purpose of helping less developed countries raise their living standards. The powers of the Bank are vested in a Board of Governors. The Bank gives loans for projects that will lead to economic growth (e.g., India’s Population Projects).

 

HQ - Washington DC, USA

 

Comprises of two institutions - International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) and International Development Association (IDA).

 

Organization Commitment - Promotion of foreign investment and international trade and facilitation of Capital investment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. UNICEF: One element that unifies and represents UNICEF. It has been specially designed to symbolize name, but also what UNICEF stand for children. Lower case letters of ‘unicef’ used in the logo are friendly and approachable. 

 

Parent and child symbol - Child as central purpose while the laurel leaves provide a link to UNICEF’s history with United Nations


Headquarters: New York.

 

 

 

Option B. UNFPA: Lead UN agency for delivering a world where every pregnancy is wanted, every childbirth is safe and every young person’s potential is fulfilled. Work involves the improvement of reproductive health; including creation of national strategies and protocols, and providing supplies and services. The organization has recently been known for its worldwide campaign against obstetric fistula and female genital mutilation.

 

 

Option D. UNDP: UNDP works as Main source of funds for technical assistance. Responsible for Sustainable development goals (SDGs)

 

HQ - New York, USA.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

WORLD BANK (WB) - An international financial institution that provides loans to developing countries for capital programs

 

Ref:  Park 26th edition- page 1017

questions.text: Dr. Reddy, the renowned Public Health specialist, is discussing strategies to combat anemia among children and pregnant women during a medical seminar in Chennai. She emphasizes the role of international and national organizations in supporting anemia control projects. As part of her presentation, Dr. Reddy mentions the support provided by a specific organization for anemia control projects in India. Which of the following organizations is known to extend its support for anemia control projects in India?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. CARE

 

Explanation:

 

CARE (Cooperative for Assistance and Relief Everywhere) founded in North America in 1945 began its operation in India in 1950. Till the end of 1980s, the primary objective of CARE - India was to provide food for children in the age group of 6-11 years.

 

From mid 1980s, CARE-India focused its food support in the ICDS programme and development of programmes in the areas of health and income supplementation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CARE supported Projects in India -

 

  • Integrated Nutrition and Health Project
  • Better Health and Nutrition Project
  • Anaemia Control Project
  • Improving Women's Health Project
  • Improved Health Care for Adolescent Girl's Project
  • Child Survival Project
  • Improving Women's Reproductive Health and Family Spacing Project
  • Konkan Integrate Development Project

 

Ref:  Park 26th edition- page 1018

questions.text: Which of the following agents is most likely classified as a Category B bioterrorism agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Brucella spp. (Brucellosis)

 

  • Category B bioterrorism agents are characterized by their moderate ease of dissemination, ability to cause moderate morbidity with low mortality, and the need for enhanced diagnostic and surveillance capabilities by the CDC.
  • Brucella spp., the causative agent of Brucellosis, fits this profile as it can be spread through aerosols or contaminated animal products and may present with non-specific flu-like symptoms, making it challenging to diagnose without specialized testing.
  • Other examples of Category B agents include Salmonella spp., Q fever (Coxiella burnetii), and Ricin toxin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacillus anthracis (Anthrax): Incorrect. Anthrax is a Category A bioterrorism agent, not Category B. Category A agents are more dangerous due to their high mortality rates, ease of dissemination, and the potential for mass casualties.

 

Option B. Yersinia pestis (Plague): Incorrect. Yersinia pestis, the causative agent of plague, is classified as a Category A bioterrorism agent due to its potential for causing high mortality and its ease of spread.

 

Option D. Variola major (Smallpox): Incorrect. Smallpox is also a Category A agent, due to its high mortality rate, ease of transmission, and potential for severe impact on public health.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: According to the WHO categorization of bioterrorism agents, Anthrax belongs to which category?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Category A

 

  • The WHO categorizes bioterrorism agents into three main categories based on their potential impact on public health and their ease of dissemination.
  • Anthrax (Bacillus anthracis) is classified as a Category A agent, which includes the highest priority agents that pose the greatest risk to national security and public health.
  • Category A agents are easily disseminated or transmitted from person to person, cause high mortality rates, and have the potential for major public health impact.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Category B: Includes agents that are moderately easy to disseminate and result in moderate morbidity rates and low mortality rates, require enhanced diagnostic capacity with enhanced surveillance.

 

Option C. Category C: Includes NEW emerging pathogens that could be engineered for mass dissemination in the future because of their availability, ease of production and dissemination, and potential for high morbidity and mortality rates.

 

Option D. Category D: Not a recognized category by WHO for bioterrorism agents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • Anthrax is the MC used bioterrorism agent
  • Small pox is the most dangerous bioterrorism agent
  • Botulism most lethal toxin wise bioterrorism agent

questions.text: Which of the following agents is not included in the WHO Category A bioterrorism list?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Brucella melitensis

 

  • Brucella melitensis, the causative agent of brucellosis, is not classified as a Category A bioterrorism agent.
  • It is a Category B agent, which is of lower priority compared to Category A agents due to its lower mortality and potential for public health impact.
  • Category A agents include pathogens that pose the highest threat due to their ease of dissemination, potential for high mortality, and ability to cause widespread panic.
  • These include Francisella tularensis (tularemia), Bacillus anthracis (anthrax), and Yersinia pestis (plague).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Francisella tularensis: A Category A agent known for causing tularemia, a highly infectious disease.

 

Option B. Bacillus anthracis: The bacterium responsible for anthrax, a well-known Category A bioterrorism agent.

 

Option C. Yersinia pestis: The bacterium that causes plague, another Category A agent due to its historical association with pandemics and high mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Category A Bioterrorism agents (WHO) include - Botulism, Tularaemia, Anthrax, Smallpox, Plague, Viral hemorrhagic fevers (Filoviruses – Ebola & Marburg; Arenaviruses – Lassa, Machupo)

choices.text: Category A - Easily transmitted and are associated with high mortality rates
Category D - Re-emerging diseases that are high priority agents
Category C - Emerging diseases that are easy to disseminate and are associated with high mortality rates
Category B - Slow to disseminate and are associated with low mortality rates

questions.text: According to the CDC classification of bioterrorism agents, which one of the following statements is untrue? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Category D - Re-emerging diseases that are high priority agents

 

  • As per the CDC, bioterrorism agents are categorized solely into three groups, namely Category A, B, and C, with no classification for a Category D.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A public health official is leading a training workshop on emergency preparedness and response to bioterrorism threats. The focus of the session is on Type-A bioterrorism agents, which are characterized by their high mortality rates, potential for major public health impact, person-to-person transmission, and the need for special action for public health preparedness. The official emphasizes the importance of recognizing these agents to ensure rapid identification and response. Which of the following is considered a Type-A bioterrorism agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bacillus anthracis

 

Explanation: Bacillus anthracis, the bacterium that causes anthrax, is classified as a Category A bioterrorism agent by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) due to its potential to be used as a bioweapon. It can produce high mortality rates, has the potential for major public health impact, and requires special action for public health preparedness. Anthrax can be transmitted through spores, which can be engineered for mass dissemination.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option (a) Coxiella burnetii: While Coxiella burnetii, the agent of Q fever, is a concern for bioterrorism, it is classified lower than Category A because it typically has a lower mortality rate and is less likely to cause widespread public health impact.
  • Option (c) Clostridium perfringens: This bacterium can cause gas gangrene and food poisoning but is not classified as a Category A bioterrorism agent due to its limited potential for widespread impact and high mortality in a bioterrorism context.
  • Option (d) NIPAH virus: Nipah virus is a significant pathogen with high mortality rates, but it is not classified as a Category A bioterrorism agent. It represents a severe natural infectious disease threat rather than one primarily associated with bioterrorism.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Category A bioterrorism agents can be easily disseminated, have high mortality rates and lead to public panic & disruption. Agents include Botulism, Tularaemia, Anthrax, Small pox, Plague, Viral haemorrhagic fevers
  • Category B bioterrorism agents are moderately easy to disseminate, cause moderate morbidity with low mortality, require enhanced diagnostic capacity with enhanced surveillance
  • Category C bioterrorism agents are new emerging pathogens that are available, have ease of production and exhibit high morbidity and mortality

questions.text:
Dr. Chandra, a senior policy advisor in the Health Ministry, is refining national biodefense strategies. She evaluates pathogens based on their classification into different categories of bioterrorism threats.

 

Which of the following pathogens would Dr. Chandra prioritize for immediate preparedness measures due to its classification as a Category A bioterrorism threat?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Smallpox

 

  • Smallpox is classified as a Category A bioterrorism threat due to its high potential to cause mass casualties and significant public panic.
  • It requires a substantial healthcare infrastructure to manage, including vaccination programs and isolation units, given its high mortality rate and potential for widespread dissemination.
  • The eradication of smallpox and the availability of existing vaccines do not diminish its potential threat if used as a bioweapon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ricin toxin: While dangerous, ricin toxin falls under Category B. It can cause significant morbidity and is moderately easy to disseminate, but does not generally lead to mass casualties like smallpox.

 

Option C. Q fever: Also a Category B threat, Q fever requires enhanced diagnostic capacity due to its moderate morbidity and relatively low mortality. It doesn’t invoke the widespread panic or require the extensive healthcare response associated with Category A agents.

 

Option D. Glanders: Glanders is another Category B threat, known for its moderate morbidity and low mortality, and like Q fever and ricin toxin, it lacks the mass casualty potential of smallpox.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
During a training session for emergency responders, a discussion focuses on the categorization of bioterrorism agents according to their threat level and potential for public health impact. Which organisms are included in Category ‘A’ for bioterrorism threats, indicating the highest priority organisms that pose a risk to national security?

 

  1. Vibrio cholera
  2. Clostridium botulinum
  3. Yersinia pestis
  4. Bacillus anthracis
  5. Burkholderia mallei
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3, 4

 

  • Category A bioterrorism agents can be easily disseminated, have high mortality rates and lead to public panic & disruption
  • Clostridium botulinum produces botulinum toxin, one of the most potent known toxins, which can result in severe and often fatal paralysis.
  • Yersinia pestis is the causative agent of plague, an infectious disease that has caused widespread pandemics with high mortality rates throughout history.
  • Bacillus anthracis is known for causing anthrax, which can be lethal when spores are inhaled.

 

Other Options:

 

Option 1. Vibrio cholera: While Vibrio cholera, the agent causing cholera, can lead to significant outbreaks and public health challenges, it is not classified under Category ‘A’ because it has lower mortality when treated and is less likely to cause social disruption comparable to Category ‘A’ agents.

 

Option 5. Burkholderia mallei: Although Burkholderia mallei, which causes glanders, is a serious pathogen, it is not typically classified under Category ‘A’. It does pose a risk but does not match the criteria of ease of dissemination and high mortality as closely as the Category ‘A’ agents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Category A Bioterrorism agents (WHO) include Botulism, Tularaemia, Anthrax, Smallpox, Plague, Viral hemorrhagic fevers (Filoviruses – Ebola & Marburg; Arenaviruses – Lassa, Machupo)

questions.text: A national security advisor is assessing potential biological threats that could be utilized in bioterrorism. Among the list of pathogens being evaluated, which one is not typically considered a primary agent for bioterrorism due to its characteristics and mode of transmission?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tuberculosis

 

Bioterrorism agents are typically categorized based on their ease of transmission, potential impact on public health, and ability to cause widespread panic and disruption. The pathogens classified as primary agents (Category A) are those considered to be the most severe and likely to be used in bioterrorism. This category includes pathogens like smallpox, plague, botulism, anthrax, tularemia, and viral hemorrhagic fevers (such as Ebola, Marburg, and Lassa viruses). These agents are characterized by high infectivity, easy dissemination, and the potential for significant mortality.

 

Tuberculosis, although a serious infectious disease, does not meet the criteria for a primary bioterrorism agent. Its transmission is generally slower and requires prolonged close contact, making it less suitable for rapid, widespread dissemination as a bioterrorism tool. Additionally, tuberculosis does not typically induce the same level of acute, severe illness in a population compared to other Category A agents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Smallpox: Smallpox is a highly contagious and deadly virus that spreads easily through respiratory droplets, making it a potent agent for bioterrorism. Its high fatality rate and historical impact on human populations make it a primary bioterrorism threat.

 

Option B. Plague: Caused by Yersinia pestis, plague can be transmitted via respiratory droplets (pneumonic plague) and can cause severe and rapidly progressing illness, often with high mortality. It is classified as a primary agent due to its potential for person-to-person transmission and rapid spread.

 

Option C. Botulism: Botulism is caused by toxins produced by Clostridium botulinum bacteria. It is the most lethal toxin by weight, and even a small quantity can cause paralysis and death. Although it does not spread from person to person, its potency makes it a primary agent for bioterrorism when introduced into food or water supplies.

 

Educational Objective:


Tuberculosis is not classified as a primary bioterrorism agent due to its transmission characteristics and lesser potential for widespread acute impact, unlike Category A agents such as smallpox, plague, and botulism.

choices.text: Smallpox is a highly contagious virus with a low mortality rate
The smallpox virus has been eradicated worldwide and is only found in laboratory stocks
Smallpox is used as a bioterrorism agent due to its relatively easiness of use
Smallpox vaccination is not effective in preventing bioterrorism-related outbreaks

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding smallpox as a bioterrorism agent?
questions.solution: Ans. B) The smallpox virus has been eradicated worldwide and is only found in laboratory stocks.

questions.text: In a discussion on biodefense strategies, a healthcare professional explains the classification of biological agents by the CDC. Which agent listed as a Category B bioterrorism agent is known primarily for posing moderate health threats and requires specific enhancements in disease surveillance and CDC's diagnostic capacity?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Epsilon toxin of Clostridium perfringens

 

The Epsilon toxin of Clostridium perfringens is classified as a Category B bioterrorism agent by the CDC. Category B agents pose moderate health threats to the public and require improvements in disease surveillance, laboratory diagnostics, and overall public health response capabilities. These agents are less lethal than Category A agents but still pose a significant concern for public safety and bioterrorism defense.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anthrax (Bacillus anthracis): Incorrect. Anthrax is a Category A agent, known for its high threat potential and severe health impacts.

 

Option C. Smallpox (Variola major): Incorrect. Smallpox is also a Category A agent, characterized by its high mortality rate and potential for widespread outbreaks.

 

Option D. Hantavirus: Incorrect. Hantavirus is not classified as a bioterrorism agent. It is typically associated with natural outbreaks and does not fit the Category B bioterrorism classification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Category B agents, such as the Epsilon toxin of Clostridium perfringens, pose moderate public health risks and necessitate enhanced disease surveillance and diagnostic capabilities.

questions.text: In a cohort study done in a community, out of those 100 vaccinated for malaria, only 6 developed the disease. At the same time, out of those 100 non-vaccinated, a total of 12 developed the disease. Find the relative risk in the study:  (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 0.5

 

To find the relative risk (RR) in this study, we first need to calculate the incidence of the disease in both the vaccinated (exposed) and non-vaccinated (non-exposed) groups.

 

Step 1: Incidence in the vaccinated group (exposed):

 

  • Number of vaccinated individuals = 100
  • Number of vaccinated individuals who developed the disease = 6
  • Incidence in the vaccinated group = 6/100 = 0.06

 

Step 2: Incidence in the non-vaccinated group (non-exposed):

 

  • Number of non-vaccinated individuals = 100
  • Number of non-vaccinated individuals who developed the disease = 12
  • Incidence in the non-vaccinated group = 12/100 = 0.12

 

Step 3: Calculate Relative Risk (RR):
 

  • RR = Incidence in the exposed group / Incidence in the non-exposed group
  • RR = 0.06 / 0.12 = 0.5

 

The relative risk of 0.5 indicates that the vaccinated individuals were half as likely to develop malaria compared to those who were not vaccinated. This suggests a protective effect of the vaccine against malaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a cohort study, the relative risk is calculated by comparing the incidence of the outcome in the exposed group to the incidence in the non-exposed group.

 

A relative risk less than 1 indicates a protective effect of the exposure, as seen in this example where vaccination reduced the risk of malaria.

choices.text: Green tea increases the risk of diabetes
Green tea decreases the risk of diabetes
Data insufficient to establish causal association
The value (0.84) tends to be close to 1, hence there is no effect

questions.text: A cohort study was carried out involving individuals who consumed green tea and those who did not, aiming to examine its impact on diabetes mellitus. The calculated risk ratio stood at 0.84. Which of the subsequent statements is accurate? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Green tea decreases the risk of diabetes

 

Green tea consumption decreases the risk of DM

 

Relative risk <1 implies negative/inverse association, i.e., risk factor is rather protective for the disease.

 

The risk ratio of 0.84 indicates that the incidence of diabetes mellitus is lower in the group of drinkers of green tea compared to the group of non-drinkers. Therefore, it can be concluded that green tea decreases the risk of diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Relative risk (RR) = Incidence among exposed/Incidence among non-exposed

 

Note - Strength of association in a cohort study is evaluated by:– Relative risk, Attributable risk (AR), Population attributable risk (PAR)

choices.text: A case-control study is typically more time-consuming to conduct compared to a cohort study.
In a cohort study, participants are selected based on their exposure status to determine the effect of the exposure on the development of disease.
Cohort studies are usually prospective, following participants over time to observe the occurrence of disease outcomes.
Case-control studies are particularly useful for investigating rare diseases because they start with cases that have the disease of interest.

questions.text: Review and evaluate the differences between case-control studies and cohort studies to understand their unique characteristics and appropriate applications. Which of the following statements about the differences between case-control and cohort studies is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A case-control study is typically more time-consuming to conduct compared to a cohort study.

 

This statement is incorrect. Case-control studies are generally quicker and less expensive to conduct because they look retrospectively at cases with the disease and compare them to controls, assessing past exposures, while cohort studies often follow participants over time, which can take longer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. In a cohort study, participants are selected based on their exposure status to determine the effect of the exposure on the development of disease: This is also correct. Cohort studies typically involve selecting participants based on whether they have been exposed to a certain risk factor and then following them to see if they develop the outcome of interest.

 

Option C. Cohort studies are usually prospective, following participants over time to observe the occurrence of disease outcomes: This is correct as well. Most cohort studies are prospective, meaning they follow participants forward in time to observe the incidence of disease. However, some cohort studies can also be retrospective.

 

Option D. Case-control studies are particularly useful for investigating rare diseases because they start with cases that have the disease of interest: This statement is correct. Case-control studies are indeed valuable in studying rare diseases, as they start with individuals who already have the disease and then look backwards to identify possible exposures or risk factors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The main point to understand here is the distinction between case-control and cohort studies:

 

  • Case-control studies are retrospective, quick, cost-effective, and ideal for studying rare diseases.
  • Cohort studies are often prospective, focusing on following participants based on exposure status to assess disease development over time. These studies are more time-consuming but provide stronger evidence for causality.

questions.text: In an epidemiological research, a nested case-control study is utilized within an ongoing cohort study. This design is particularly advantageous compared to a standard case-control study in addressing certain methodological challenges. Which of the following issues does a nested case-control study specifically help to avoid?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Temporal association

 

  • The nested case-control study design is crucial for ensuring that the exposure precedes the outcome, thus establishing a clear temporal relationship.
  • This design selects cases (individuals who develop the outcome) and controls (those who do not) from participants who have already been followed forward in time within a cohort study.
  • Therefore, the exposure status is already known before the outcome occurs, which helps avoid the retrospective determination of exposure that plagues traditional case-control studies and can lead to temporal ambiguity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Confounding bias: While nested case-control studies can provide better adjustment for confounders due to pre-collected data, they do not inherently eliminate confounding bias compared to other study designs.

 

Option C. Need for long follow-up: Nested case-control studies reduce the need for new long-term follow-up since they use pre-existing cohort data where follow-up has already been conducted. However, their primary strength over traditional case-control studies lies in their ability to clarify the temporal sequence.

 

Option D. Randomization: Randomization is a method used in experimental designs, such as randomized controlled trials, to assign exposures or interventions. It is not typically a component of observational studies like case-control studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NESTED CASE CONTROL STUDY

 

  •  
  • Is a hybrid design where ‘a case control study is nested in a cohort study’.
  • Is predominantly a type of Cohort study (due to forward direction).
  • Usefulness limited for studies involving ‘rare diseases AND whose diagnostic tests are very expensive’.

questions.text: A study was conducted to evaluate the intraocular pressure (IOP) among a cohort of 400 participants following a normal distribution. The analysis reported a mean IOP of 25 mm Hg with a standard deviation of 1.0 mm Hg. 95% participants IOP will lie between ………………..
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 23-27 mm Hg

 

In a normal distribution, 95% of values lie within ±2 standard deviations from the mean. The formula used is:

 

Range = Mean ± 2 × Standard Deviation

 

Given:

 

  • Mean IOP = 25 mm Hg
  • Standard Deviation = 1 mm Hg

 

Applying the formula:

 

25 ± (2×1) = 25±2

 

Thus, 95% of participants will have IOP values between 23 mm Hg and 27 mm Hg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a normal distribution, 95% of values lie within ±2 standard deviations from the mean.

choices.text: Descriptive studies are primarily used to test specific hypotheses.
Analytic studies are commonly used to formulate initial hypotheses.
Descriptive studies represent the initial phase in understanding the patterns and occurrences of disease.
Analytic studies primarily focus on observing the distribution of disease across populations.

questions.text: A group of researchers are discussing the foundational approaches of epidemiological studies as they plan their next study on chronic disease patterns in a metropolitan area. Which of the following statements accurately differentiates descriptive studies from analytic studies?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Descriptive studies represent the initial phase in understanding the patterns and occurrences of disease.

 

In epidemiology, descriptive studies are the first step in investigating disease patterns and formulating hypotheses. These studies focus on describing the distribution of diseases within a population by examining factors such as time, place, and person. Descriptive studies do not test specific hypotheses but rather provide a basis for identifying potential associations or risk factors that require further exploration.

 

Analytic studies, on the other hand, are conducted after hypotheses have been generated through descriptive research. The purpose of analytic studies is to test specific hypotheses about the relationships between exposures and outcomes. Common analytic study designs include cohort studies, case-control studies, cross-sectional studies, and ecological studies.

 

To summarize:

 

  • Descriptive Studies: Formulate initial hypotheses by identifying patterns and trends.
  • Analytic Studies: Test specific hypotheses by analyzing relationships between potential risk factors and outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Descriptive studies are primarily used to test specific hypotheses: Incorrect, as descriptive studies are not used to test hypotheses; they are primarily observational and hypothesis-generating.

 

Option B. Analytic studies are commonly used to formulate initial hypotheses: Incorrect, as hypothesis formulation is typically the role of descriptive studies, not analytic studies.

 

Option D. Analytic studies primarily focus on observing the distribution of disease across populations: Incorrect, as observing the distribution of disease is a characteristic of descriptive studies, not analytic studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Descriptive studies are the initial phase in epidemiology, focusing on describing disease patterns and formulating hypotheses. Analytic studies are conducted to test these hypotheses and examine the relationships between risk factors and disease outcomes.

choices.text: Associated both with exposure and disease
Distributed equally between study and control groups

questions.text: Which one of the following is FALSE regarding confounding factors in epidemiological studies? (FMGE JUNE 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Distributed equally between study and control groups 

 

Explanation: 

 

A confounding factor is a variable that is associated with both the exposure and the  outcome, and it can distort the apparent relationship between the two. For a variable to be a  confounder, it must meet the following criteria: 

 

• It is associated with the exposure. 

• It is an independent risk factor for the outcome. 

• It is not an intermediate step in the causal pathway between the exposure and the outcome. 

 

In a well-conducted study, confounding factors are typically distributed unequally between the study  and control groups, which is why they must be controlled for through various methods such as  matching, randomization, stratification, or statistical modeling. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Associated both with exposure and disease: This is true. A confounding factor must be associated with both the exposure and the  outcome. 

 

Option C. Independent risk factor for disease: This is true. A confounding factor must be an independent risk factor for the outcome. 

 

Option D. Source of bias in interpretation: This is true. Confounding can introduce bias into the interpretation of the relationship  between exposure and outcome, making it appear stronger or weaker 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Confounding factors are not typically distributed equally between study and  control groups. Effective study design and analysis techniques are necessary to control for these  confounders to ensure accurate interpretation of results.

choices.text: Retrospective Cohort Study
Prospective Cohort Study
Case-Control Study
Cross-Sectional Study

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman presents to her obstetrician for a routine prenatal visit. She has no significant medical history but admits to smoking about five cigarettes a day since her teenage years. Concerned about the potential effects of her smoking on her unborn child, she inquires about the risks. Recent studies, including one conducted by an obstetrician at a well-known medical university, have focused on the correlation between maternal smoking during pregnancy and various neonatal outcomes. This particular study tracked expectant mothers' smoking habits and the subsequent birth weights of their newborns. Based on this information, which type of epidemiological study design is most likely being used in the research mentioned?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Prospective Cohort Study

 

Explanation:

 

A prospective cohort study is an observational study where subjects are followed over time from exposure to outcome. In the context of the study described, pregnant women (the cohort) are being followed prospectively from the point of their smoking exposure to the outcome of interest, which is the birth weight of their newborns. This design allows for the temporal relationship between exposure and outcome to be established, which is crucial in understanding causal inferences.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Retrospective Cohort Study: This study design also follows a group of individuals based on exposure status to an outcome, but the data collection starts after the outcomes have occurred, often relying on past records. This was not the design used in the study since the outcomes were recorded after the exposure was identified, not from past records.
  • Option C. Case-Control Study: Case-control studies start with the outcome and then look backward to investigate exposures. This design is not suitable when the outcome has not yet occurred, as was the case in the study described.
  • Option D. Cross-Sectional Study: Cross-sectional studies assess both exposure and outcome at a single point in time. This design does not track changes over time and therefore cannot establish a temporal relationship between exposure and outcome, making it inappropriate for the study in question.


 

Educational Objective
